commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku dashboard

[1mdisplay information about favorite apps[22m

[1mUsage:[22m heroku apps:create [APP] [34m[flags][39m

[1mcreates a new app[22m

APP  [2mname of app to create[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -b, --buildpack BUILDPACK  [2mbuildpack url to use for this app[22m
 -n, --no-remote            [2mdo not create a git remote[22m
 -o, --org ORG              [2mteam to use[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE        [2mthe git remote to create, default "heroku"[22m
 -s, --stack STACK          [2mthe stack to create the app on[22m
 -t, --team TEAM            [2mteam to use[22m
 --addons ADDONS            [2mcomma-delimited list of addons to install[22m
 --json                     [2moutput in json format[22m
 --region REGION            [2mspecify region for the app to run in[22m
 --space SPACE              [2mthe private space to create the app in[22m
 --ssh-git                  [2muse SSH git protocol for local git remote[22m

Examples:

    $ heroku apps:create
    Creating app... done, stack is cedar-14
    https://floating-dragon-42.heroku.com/ | https://git.heroku.com/floating-dragon-42.git

    # or just
    $ heroku create

    # specify a buildpack
    $ heroku apps:create --buildpack https://github.com/some/buildpack.git

    # specify a name
    $ heroku apps:create example

    # create a staging app
    $ heroku apps:create example-staging --remote staging

    # create an app in the eu region
    $ heroku apps:create --region eu

[1mUsage:[22m heroku create [APP] [34m[flags][39m

[1mcreates a new app[22m

APP  [2mname of app to create[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -b, --buildpack BUILDPACK  [2mbuildpack url to use for this app[22m
 -n, --no-remote            [2mdo not create a git remote[22m
 -o, --org ORG              [2mteam to use[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE        [2mthe git remote to create, default "heroku"[22m
 -s, --stack STACK          [2mthe stack to create the app on[22m
 -t, --team TEAM            [2mteam to use[22m
 --addons ADDONS            [2mcomma-delimited list of addons to install[22m
 --json                     [2moutput in json format[22m
 --region REGION            [2mspecify region for the app to run in[22m
 --space SPACE              [2mthe private space to create the app in[22m
 --ssh-git                  [2muse SSH git protocol for local git remote[22m

Examples:

    $ heroku apps:create
    Creating app... done, stack is cedar-14
    https://floating-dragon-42.heroku.com/ | https://git.heroku.com/floating-dragon-42.git

    # or just
    $ heroku create

    # specify a buildpack
    $ heroku apps:create --buildpack https://github.com/some/buildpack.git

    # specify a name
    $ heroku apps:create example

    # create a staging app
    $ heroku apps:create example-staging --remote staging

    # create an app in the eu region
    $ heroku apps:create --region eu

[1mUsage:[22m heroku apps:destroy [APP] [34m[flags][39m

[1mpermanently destroy an app[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP          [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -c, --confirm CONFIRM
 -r, --remote REMOTE    [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

This will also destroy all add-ons on the app.

[1mUsage:[22m heroku destroy [APP] [34m[flags][39m

[1mpermanently destroy an app[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP          [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -c, --confirm CONFIRM
 -r, --remote REMOTE    [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

This will also destroy all add-ons on the app.

[1mUsage:[22m heroku apps:delete [APP] [34m[flags][39m

[1mpermanently destroy an app[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP          [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -c, --confirm CONFIRM
 -r, --remote REMOTE    [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

This will also destroy all add-ons on the app.

[1mUsage:[22m heroku apps:errors [34m[flags][39m

[1mview app errors[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m
 --dyno               [2mshow only dyno errors[22m
 --hours HOURS        [2mnumber of hours to look back (default 24)[22m
 --json               [2moutput in json format[22m
 --router             [2mshow only router errors[22m

[1mUsage:[22m heroku apps [34m[flags][39m

[1mlist your apps[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -A, --all          [2minclude apps in all teams[22m
 -o, --org ORG      [2mteam to use[22m
 -p, --personal     [2mlist apps in personal account when a default team is set[22m
 -s, --space SPACE  [2mfilter by space[22m
 -t, --team TEAM    [2mteam to use[22m
 --json             [2moutput in json format[22m

[1mUsage:[22m heroku list [34m[flags][39m

[1mlist your apps[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -A, --all          [2minclude apps in all teams[22m
 -o, --org ORG      [2mteam to use[22m
 -p, --personal     [2mlist apps in personal account when a default team is set[22m
 -s, --space SPACE  [2mfilter by space[22m
 -t, --team TEAM    [2mteam to use[22m
 --json             [2moutput in json format[22m

[1mUsage:[22m heroku apps:list [34m[flags][39m

[1mlist your apps[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -A, --all          [2minclude apps in all teams[22m
 -o, --org ORG      [2mteam to use[22m
 -p, --personal     [2mlist apps in personal account when a default team is set[22m
 -s, --space SPACE  [2mfilter by space[22m
 -t, --team TEAM    [2mteam to use[22m
 --json             [2moutput in json format[22m

[1mUsage:[22m heroku apps:info [APP] [34m[flags][39m

[1mshow detailed app information[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -j, --json
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m
 -s, --shell          [2moutput more shell friendly key/value pairs[22m

Examples:

    $ heroku apps:info
    === example
    Git URL:   https://git.heroku.com/example.git
    Repo Size: 5M
    ...

    $ heroku apps:info --shell
    git_url=https://git.heroku.com/example.git
    repo_size=5000000
    ...

[1mUsage:[22m heroku info [APP] [34m[flags][39m

[1mshow detailed app information[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -j, --json
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m
 -s, --shell          [2moutput more shell friendly key/value pairs[22m

Examples:

    $ heroku apps:info
    === example
    Git URL:   https://git.heroku.com/example.git
    Repo Size: 5M
    ...

    $ heroku apps:info --shell
    git_url=https://git.heroku.com/example.git
    repo_size=5000000
    ...

commands.description: open the app in a web browser
commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku apps:open [PATH] [34m[flags][39m

[1mopen the app in a web browser[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

Examples:

    $ heroku open -a myapp
    # opens https://myapp.herokuapp.com

    $ heroku open -a myapp /foo
    # opens https://myapp.herokuapp.com/foo
helpLine: [2mopen the app in a web browser[22m

commands.description: open the app in a web browser
commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku open [PATH] [34m[flags][39m

 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

Examples:

helpLine: [2mopen the app in a web browser[22m

commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku apps:rename NEWNAME [34m[flags][39m

[1mrename an app[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m
 --ssh-git            [2muse ssh git protocol instead of https[22m

This will locally update the git remote if it is set to the old app.

Example:

    $ heroku apps:rename --app oldname newname
    https://newname.herokuapp.com/ | https://git.heroku.com/newname.git
    Git remote heroku updated

[1mUsage:[22m heroku rename NEWNAME [34m[flags][39m

[1mrename an app[22m

 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m
 --ssh-git            [2muse ssh git protocol instead of https[22m

This will locally update the git remote if it is set to the old app.

Example:

    $ heroku apps:rename --app oldname newname
    https://newname.herokuapp.com/ | https://git.heroku.com/newname.git
    Git remote heroku updated

commands.description: set the stack of an app
commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku apps:stacks:set STACK [34m[flags][39m

[1mset the stack of an app[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

Example:

    $ heroku stack:set cedar-14 -a myapp
    Stack set. Next release on myapp will use cedar-14.
    Run git push heroku master to create a new release on myapp.

commands.description: add new app buildpack, inserting into list of buildpacks if necessary
commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku buildpacks:add URL [34m[flags][39m

[1madd new app buildpack, inserting into list of buildpacks if necessary[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -i, --index INDEX    [2mthe 1-based index of the URL in the list of URLs[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

Example:

     $ heroku buildpacks:add -i 1 https://github.com/heroku/heroku-buildpack-ruby
helpLine: [2madd new app buildpack, inserting into list of buildpacks if necessary[22m

commands.description: display a config value for an app
commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku config:get KEY [34m[flags][39m

[1mdisplay a config value for an app[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m
 -s, --shell          [2moutput config var in shell format[22m

Example:

    $ heroku config:get RAILS_ENV
    production
helpLine: [2mdisplay a config value for an app[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

commands.description: set one or more config vars
commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku config:set [34m[flags][39m

[1mset one or more config vars[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

Examples:

    $ heroku config:set RAILS_ENV=staging
    Setting config vars and restarting example... done, v10
    RAILS_ENV: staging
    
    $ heroku config:set RAILS_ENV=staging RACK_ENV=staging
    Setting config vars and restarting example... done, v11
    RAILS_ENV: staging
    RACK_ENV:  staging

commands.description: set one or more config vars
commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku config:add [34m[flags][39m

commands.description: add an SSH key for a user
commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku keys:add [KEY] [34m[flags][39m

[1madd an SSH key for a user[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -y, --yes  [2mautomatically answer yes for all prompts[22m

if no KEY is specified, will try to find ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub

Examples:

    $ heroku keys:add
    Could not find an existing public key.
    Would you like to generate one? [Yn] y
    Generating new SSH public key.
    Uploading SSH public key /.ssh/id_rsa.pub... done

    $ heroku keys:add /my/key.pub
    Uploading SSH public key /my/key.pub... done
helpLine: [2madd an SSH key for a user[22m

commands.description: remove all SSH keys for current user
commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku keys:clear

[1mremove all SSH keys for current user[22m

[1mremove an SSH key from the user[22m

[1mUsage:[22m heroku notifications [34m[flags][39m

[1mdisplay notifications[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m
 --all                [2mview all notifications (not just the ones for the current app)[22m
 --json               [2moutput in json format[22m
 --read               [2mshow notifications already read[22m

[1mUsage:[22m heroku ps [TYPE [TYPE ...]] [34m[flags][39m

[1mlist dynos for an app[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m
 --json               [2mdisplay as json[22m

Examples:

    $ heroku ps
    === run: one-off dyno
    run.1: up for 5m: bash
    
    === web: bundle exec thin start -p $PORT
    web.1: created for 30s
    
    $ heroku ps run # specifying types
    === run: one-off dyno
    run.1: up for 5m: bash

[1mUsage:[22m heroku ps:restart [DYNO] [34m[flags][39m

[1mrestart app dynos[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

if DYNO is not specified, restarts all dynos on app

Examples:

    $ heroku ps:restart web.1
    Restarting web.1 dyno... done

    $ heroku ps:restart web
    Restarting web dynos... done

    $ heroku ps:restart
    Restarting dynos... done

[1mUsage:[22m heroku dyno:restart [DYNO] [34m[flags][39m

[1mrestart app dynos[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

if DYNO is not specified, restarts all dynos on app

Examples:

    $ heroku ps:restart web.1
    Restarting web.1 dyno... done

    $ heroku ps:restart web
    Restarting web dynos... done

    $ heroku ps:restart
    Restarting dynos... done

[1mUsage:[22m heroku restart [DYNO] [34m[flags][39m

[1mrestart app dynos[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

if DYNO is not specified, restarts all dynos on app

Examples:

    $ heroku ps:restart web.1
    Restarting web.1 dyno... done

    $ heroku ps:restart web
    Restarting web dynos... done

    $ heroku ps:restart
    Restarting dynos... done

commands.description: scale dyno quantity up or down
commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku ps:scale [34m[flags][39m

[1mscale dyno quantity up or down[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

Appending a size (eg. web=2:Standard-2X) allows simultaneous scaling and resizing.

Omitting any arguments will display the app's current dyno formation, in a
format suitable for passing back into ps:scale.

Examples:

    $ heroku ps:scale web=3:Standard-2X worker+1
    Scaling dynos... done, now running web at 3:Standard-2X, worker at 1:Standard-1X.

    $ heroku ps:scale
    web=3:Standard-2X worker=1:Standard-1X

commands.description: scale dyno quantity up or down
commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku dyno:scale [34m[flags][39m

[1mscale dyno quantity up or down[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

Appending a size (eg. web=2:Standard-2X) allows simultaneous scaling and resizing.

Omitting any arguments will display the app's current dyno formation, in a
format suitable for passing back into ps:scale.

Examples:

    $ heroku ps:scale web=3:Standard-2X worker+1
    Scaling dynos... done, now running web at 3:Standard-2X, worker at 1:Standard-1X.

    $ heroku ps:scale
    web=3:Standard-2X worker=1:Standard-1X

[1mUsage:[22m heroku ps:stop DYNO [34m[flags][39m

[1mstop app dyno[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

stop app dyno or dyno type

Examples:

    $ heroku ps:stop run.1828
    Stopping run.1828 dyno... done

    $ heroku ps:stop run
    Stopping run dynos... done

 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m

stop app dyno or dyno type

stop app dyno or dyno type

Examples:

    $ heroku ps:stop run.1828
    Stopping run.1828 dyno... done

    Stopping run dynos... done

[1mUsage:[22m heroku kill DYNO [34m[flags][39m

[1mstop app dyno[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m

stop app dyno or dyno type

Examples:

    $ heroku ps:stop run.1828
    Stopping run.1828 dyno... done

    $ heroku ps:stop run
    Stopping run dynos... done

[1mUsage:[22m heroku ps:type [34m[flags][39m

[1mmanage dyno sizes[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

Called with no arguments shows the current dyno size.

Called with one argument sets the size.
Where SIZE is one of free|hobby|standard-1x|standard-2x|performance

Called with 1..n TYPE=SIZE arguments sets the quantity per type.

[1mUsage:[22m heroku ps:resize [34m[flags][39m

[1mmanage dyno sizes[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

Called with no arguments shows the current dyno size.

Called with one argument sets the size.
Where SIZE is one of free|hobby|standard-1x|standard-2x|performance

Called with 1..n TYPE=SIZE arguments sets the quantity per type.

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

[1mUsage:[22m heroku dyno:type [34m[flags][39m

[1mmanage dyno sizes[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

Called with no arguments shows the current dyno size.

Called with one argument sets the size.
Where SIZE is one of free|hobby|standard-1x|standard-2x|performance

Called with 1..n TYPE=SIZE arguments sets the quantity per type.

[1mUsage:[22m heroku dyno:resize [34m[flags][39m

[1mmanage dyno sizes[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m

Called with one argument sets the size.

commands.description: display the releases for an app
commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku releases [34m[flags][39m

[1mdisplay the releases for an app[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -n, --num NUM        [2mnumber of releases to show[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m
 --json               [2moutput releases in json format[22m

Example:

    $ heroku releases
    === example Releases
    v1 Config add FOO_BAR email@example.com 2015/11/17 17:37:41 (~ 1h ago)
    v2 Config add BAR_BAZ email@example.com 2015/11/17 17:37:41 (~ 1h ago)
    v3 Config add BAZ_QUX email@example.com 2015/11/17 17:37:41 (~ 1h ago)

commands.description: view detailed information for a release
commands.help:
[1mUsage:[22m heroku releases:info [RELEASE] [34m[flags][39m

[1mview detailed information for a release[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m
 -s, --shell          [2moutput in shell format[22m
 --json               [2moutput in json format[22m

[1mUsage:[22m heroku releases:output [RELEASE] [34m[flags][39m

[1mView the release command output[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

[1mUsage:[22m heroku releases:rollback [RELEASE] [34m[flags][39m

[1mrollback to a previous release[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

If RELEASE is not specified, it will rollback one release

[1mUsage:[22m heroku rollback [RELEASE] [34m[flags][39m

[1mrollback to a previous release[22m

[34mFlags:[39m
 -a, --app APP        [2mapp to run command against[22m
 -r, --remote REMOTE  [2mgit remote of app to use[22m

If RELEASE is not specified, it will rollback one release
